{{redirect|ISSC}} {{Infobox organization |name = International Social Science Council |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = ISSC |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = ISSC |motto = |formation = {{Start date and age|1952}} |extinction = |type = [[International nongovernmental organization|INGO]] |status = |purpose = |headquarters = |location = [[Paris]], {{flagcountry|France}} |region_served = Worldwide |membership = |language = English |leader_title = President |leader_name = Alberto Martinelli, {{flagcountry|Italy}} |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.worldsocialscience.org/ ISSC Official website] |remarks = }}
The '''International Social Science Council''' ('''ISSC''') was an international organisation promoting the [[social sciences|social sciences, including the economic and behavioural sciences]]. It was founded in 1952, under the auspices of [[UNESCO]]. 6-9 Oct 1952, Paris (France), following a Resolution at the 6th UNESCO General Conference in 1951. Statutes: adopted 19 Sep 1972; completed and revised 14 Nov 1979; revised: 17 Dec 1985; 3 Dec 1992; 27 Nov 1998; 8 Nov 2006; 10 Dec 2010. Registered in accordance with French Law.
In 2018 the ISSC merged with the [[International Council for Science|International Council for Science (ICSU)]] to create the [[International Science Council]].
==Mission== The mission of the ISSC was to advance the social sciences - their quality, novelty and utility - in all parts of the world: * To advance social science research across national and regional boundaries; * To support social science capacity building, particularly in countries and regions where it is currently not well developed; * To provide a central clearinghouse for the collection, interpretation, analysis and dissemination of data on social science resources, their availability for research and their impact on society; * To broaden interdisciplinary collaboration among the social sciences; * To expand exchange and joint work between the social sciences, the humanities and other sciences; * To link social science knowledge effectively to public policies and local needs in order to improve the quality of people's lives; * To promote the social science literacy of citizens.
The activities of the Council were guided by the principles of academic freedom, pursuit of excellence, equitable access to scientific information and data, unfettered conduct of science, open communication and transparency, accountability, and the use of knowledge for societal value. In addition, the Council sought to support the participation of women, minorities and others under-represented in social science research.
==Governance and structure== The ISSC was governed by a General Assembly, comprising the Council’s membership. The General Assembly met every three years to review the Council’s activities and determine the general direction of its future work.
The ISSC Executive Committee was elected by the General Assembly and acted as the Council’s governing body. It consisted of the President, two Vice-Presidents and a Treasurer, as well as ten further members (Ordinary Members).
The General Assembly, on recommendation of the Executive Committee, approved the appointment of the Executive Director, who headed the Council’s Secretariat, and served as an ex-officio member of the Executive Committee and of all appointed (standing or ad hoc) committees of the ISSC.
The Council was advised and guided by individuals from around the world who volunteered their time to serve on various ISSC Committees and Working Groups.
==Activities== The ISSC led a number of flagship activities and was a partner on many collaborative initiatives.
===World Social Science Report=== The ISSC produced the World Social Science Report every three years, as part of its strategic partnership with [[UNESCO]]. The reports aim to address important social science challenges, take stock of social science contributions and capacities, and to make recommendations for future research, practice and policy.
* The World Social Science Report 2010: Knowledge Divides was prepared by the ISSC and published by UNESCO in June 2010. It reviewed social science knowledge production and use in different regions of the world and assessed how the social sciences are evolving in the face of unequal conditions and diverging trends. * The World Social Science Report 2013: Changing Global Environments was prepared by the ISSC and co-published with UNESCO and the [[OECD]]. It was launched at UNESCO in Paris in November 2013. * The World Social Science Report 2016: Challenging Inequalities – Pathways to a Just World was prepared by the ISSC in collaboration with the [[Institute of Development Studies|Institute of Development Studies (IDS)]], and co-published with UNESCO. It was launched in Stockholm on September 22 2016.
===World Social Science Forum=== The ISSC convened the World Social Science Forum. These events gather researchers, funders, policymakers, and other stakeholders to debate topics of global significance and to determine future priorities for international social science.
* The ISSC convened the first ever World Social Science Forum in Bergen, Norway, 10-12 May 2009, on the topic 'One planet - worlds apart?' * The second World Social Science Forum, 'Social Transformations and the Digital Age', took place in Montreal, Canada, in October 2013. * The third World Social Science Forum, 'Transforming Global Relations for a Just World', took place in Durban, South Africa, 13-16 September 2015. * The fourth World Social Science Forum will take place in Fukuoka, Japan, in September 2018. The theme is 'Security and Equality for Sustainable Futures'.
===Transformations to Sustainability=== Transformations to Sustainability (T2S) is a research programme supporting social-science-led research on social transformations to greater sustainability. The programme is funded by the [[Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency|Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida)]] and has supported 38 seed projects (September 2014 to March 2015) and three Transformative Knowledge Networks (December 2015 to December 2018). The programme aims to build on the networks of knowledge gathered through the seed projects and Transformative Knowledge Networks to create and leave behind a lasting global knowledge base.
The Transformations to Sustainability programme contributes to [[Future Earth]].
===Programmes and networks=== The ISSC initiated and supported several international research programmes with the objective of fostering comparative, interdisciplinary research by setting up networks of social scientists from different disciplines and regions of the world.The ISSC co-sponsored a number of international research programmes and networks around various themes, such as the environment, disaster risk, poverty and gender. These initiatives were undertaken in partnership with various partners and other organisations around the world. * [http://www.crop.org/ Comparative Research Programme on Poverty] * [[Future Earth]] * [[International Human Dimensions Programme]] * [http://www.irdrinternational.org/ Integrated Research on Disaster Risk] * [http://www.csun.edu/~isscggd/ Gender, Globalisation and Democratisation Network]
===Prizes=== The ISSC awarded two prestigious international prizes: the [[Stein Rokkan Prize for Comparative Social Science Research]] and the Foundation Mattei Dogan Prize for Excellence in Interdisciplinary Research.
Nominations for the prize were made by ISSC members or other professional associations in various disciplines, as well as by universities and academic institutions. The selection of a winner is made by an international jury of scholars.
===World Social Science Fellows=== From 2012 to 2015 the ISSC led the World Social Science Fellows programme, an international scientific programme to support early-career researchers in the social sciences, with the aim of fostering a new generation of globally-networked research leaders who will collaborate in addressing global problems with particular relevance for low and middle income countries.
===ISSC Members=== * [[Academy of the Social Sciences in Australia]] * [http://www.theacss.org/ Arab Council for the Social Sciences] * [http://www.anpocs.com Association Nacional de Pos-Graduacao e Pesquisa em ciencias sociais (ANPOCS)] * [http://www.aassrec.org Association of Asian Social Science Research Councils (AASSREC)] * [[British Academy]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120901021951/http://www.cass.net.cn/ Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (CASS)] * [[:es:Consejo Latinoamericano de Ciencias Sociales|Latinoamericano de Ciencias Sociales (CLACSO)]] * [[Council for the Development of Social Science Research in Africa|Council for the Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA)]] * [http://www.cas.cz The Czech Academy of Sciences (CAS)] * [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft|Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG)]] * [[Economic and Social Research Council|Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC)]] * [[European Association of Development Research and Training Institutes|European Association of Development Research and Training Institutes (EADI)]] * [[European Consortium for Political Research|European Consortium for Political Research (ECPR)]] * [[Human Sciences Research Council (South Africa)|Human Sciences Research Council of South Africa]] (HSRC) * [[Indian Council of Social Science Republic of Korea|National Academy of Sciences, Republic of Korea (NAS)]] * [[National Research Foundation of South Africa|National Research Foundation]] * [[Netherlands Organisation for Scientific Research|Netherlands Organisation for Scientific Research (NWO)]] * [http://www.ossrea.net Organization for Social Science Research in Eastern and Southern Africa (OSSREA)] * [http://www.pssc.org.ph/ Philippine Social Science Council (PSSC)] * [[Research Council of Norway|Research Council of Norway (RCN)]] * [http://www.trc.gov.om The Research Council Oman] * [[Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences|Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences (KNAW)]] * [[The Royal Society of New Zealand|The Royal Society of New Zealand (RSNZ)]] * [http://www.scj.go.jp/en/sca Science Council of Asia (SCA)] * [http://www.scj.go.jp/en/ Science Council of Japan] * [[Slovak Academy of Sciences|Slovak Academy of Sciences (SAS)]] * [[Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada|Social Science and Humanities Research Council of Canada (SSHRC)]] * [[Social Science Research Council|Social Science Research Council (SSRC)]] * [[Society for Social Studies of Science|Society for Social Studies of Science (4S)]] * [http://www.sagw.ch/en/sagw.html Swiss Academy of Humanities and Social Sciences (SAHS)] * [[Transnational Institute|Transnational Institute (TNI)]] * [http://www.tuba.gov.tr/ Turkish Academy of Science (TUBA)] * [http://www.iuaes.org World Anthropological Union (WAU)] * [[World Association for Public Opinion Research|World Association for Public Opinion Research (WAPOR)]] * [[Bergen University|The University of Bergen (UIB)]]

{{Orphan|date=August 2018}}
[[File:JK Everest May 2012.jpg|thumb|Jon Kedrowski on Everest, May 2012]]
'''Jonathan James Kedrowski''' (born May 12, 1979) is an author, ski-mountaineer, and geographer from [[Colorado]]. He is best known for summiting and camping overnight on the summit of all of Colorado's [[Fourteener]]s (mountains over 14,000 feet) in 2011.
==Early life and education== Kedrowski is the son of Robert Allan Kedrowski and Barbara Jean Kedrowski.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} He was born and raised in [[Vail, Colorado]].{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} He earned a bachelor's degree from [[Valparaiso University]] in 2002, and a Masters of Arts in Environmental Geography from the [[University of South Florida]] in 2006.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} In 2010, he earned a PhD in Environmental Geography from [[Texas State University]],<ref name="cwu.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.cwu.edu/cwu-geography-professor-assists-climbers-everest-wake-tragedy|title=CWU Geography Professor Assists Climbers on Everest in Wake of Tragedy|publisher=}}</ref> and he has worked as an assistant professor in the Department of Geography at [[Central Washington University]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyrecordnews.com/top_story/former-cwu-professor-recounts-harrowing-tale-from-mount-everest/article_669806fc-bfa6-11e1-9205-0019bb2963f4.html|title=Former CWU professor recounts harrowing tale from Mount Everest|author=Josh Petrie|date=26 June 2012|work=Daily Record}}</ref><ref name="cwu.edu"/>
==Mountaineering== Between 1996 and 1999, Kedrowski summited all 55 of Colorado's Fourteeners.<ref>[https://www.cmc.org/Portals/0/GoverningDocs/14ers%20Master_Nov2012.pdf EVERYONE WHO HAS COMPLETED THE COLORADO FOURTEENERS] (cmc.org)</ref> In 2011, Kedrowski summitted, camped, and spent the night on top of all 55 peaks over the course of 95 days. According to ''[[The Denver Post]]'', Kedrowski was the first person to accomplish this feat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/ci_23185876/jon-kedrowski-spends-night-all-colorados-fourteeners|title=Jon Kedrowski spends a night on all of Colorado's fourteeners|author=John Meyer|date=7 May 2013|publisher=The Denver Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/10/27/sleeping-on-colorado-summits_n_1062657.html|title=Jon Kedrowski Successfully Summits, Spends Night On, Every 14,000+ Foot Colorado Mountain|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref> In 2012, he published a book about the experience, ''Sleeping on the Summits, Colorado Fourteener High Bivys'' <ref>[http://www.westcliffepublishers.com/search.php?search=sleeping+on+the+summits Sleeping on the Summits] (Westcliff Books)</ref>
In 2012, Kedrowski, successfully climbed Mount Everest, reaching the summit on May 26, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/breakingnews/ci_20741923/jon-kedrowski-avon-summits-mount-everest|title=Jon Kedrowski of Avon summits Mount Everest|author=Randy Wyrick Vail Daily|date=30 May 2012|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/30/jon-kedrowski-avon-man-re_n_1556538.html|title=Jon Kedrowski, Avon Man, Reaches Summit Of Mt. Everest After Day Of Tragedy On Mountain That Left Several Dead (VIDEO)|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kwgn.com/2012/05/29/colorado-mountain-climber-talks-about-getting-to-the-top-of-mt-everest/|title=Colorado mountain climber talks about getting to the top of Mt. Everest|work=Channel 2 News}}</ref> During an earlier summit attempt on May 19–20, Kedrowski was present during one of the deadliest days in Everest history, when violent weather and a "traffic jam" near the summit led to the deaths of four climbers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2012/05/25/climbing-geographer-nears-mount-everest-summit/|title=Geographer reaches Mount Everest summit|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/25/travel/everest-2012-anniversary/index.html|title=Striving for Everest: World's highest battle - CNN.com|author=Ashley Strickland, CNN|date=25 May 2013|work=CNN}}</ref> Kedrowski's summit was followed closely and featured on the DatelineNBC Documentary "Into the Death Zone" <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/video/dateline/52943468/|title=Into the Death Zone -Video on NBCNews.com|work=NBC News}}</ref> which won the 2014 Edward R Morrow Award for best Sound and Video.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtdna.org/content/2014_national_edward_r_murrow_award_winners#Network/|title=Network Radio and Television Edward R Murrow Award Winners 2014}}</ref>
In 2014, Kedrowski skied 20 Cascade Volcanoes in 30 days, camping on the summits of 7 of the more notable volcanoes such as Mount Shasta, Mount Hood, Mount Adams, Mount Baker, and Mount Rainier.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2014/06/09/jon-kedrowski-summits-skis-20-highest-volcanoes-in-pacific-northwest-in-30-days/|title=Jon Kedrowski summits, skis 20 highest volcanoes in Pacific Northwest in 30 days - Denver Post | author=Jason Blevins, Denver Post|date=9 June 2014|work=Denver Post}}</ref> His adventure was chronicled in his second book "Skiing and Sleeping on the Summits: Cascade Volcanoes of the Pacific Northwest" which was officially released in April 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mountaineersbooks.org/Skiing-and-Sleeping-on-the-Summits-Cascade-Volcanoes-of-the-Pacific-Northwest-P1675.aspx/|title=Skiing and Sleeping on the Summits: Cascade Volcanoes of the Pacific Northwest Skiing 20 Peaks in 30 Days|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602141058/http://www.mountaineersbooks.org/Skiing-and-Sleeping-on-the-Summits-Cascade-Volcanoes-of-the-Pacific-Northwest-P1675.aspx|archivedate=2016-06-02|df=}}</ref>
Kedrowski was at the Mt. Everest Basecamp when the [[April 2015 Nepal earthquake]] struck, causing [[2015 Mount Everest avalanches|avalanches]] on the mountain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/videos/world/2015/04/27/nr-nepal-earthquake-everest-jon-kedrowski.cnn|title=Man describes Everest avalanche experience - CNN Video|work=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mensjournal.com/expert-advice/survival-stories-from-mount-everest-20150428/jon-kedrowski-at-base-camp|title=Jon Kedrowski: At Base Camp|work=Men's Journal}}</ref> while injuring nearly 100.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2015/04/150426-everest-earthquake-basecamp-nepal-himalaya-climbing-sherpas/|title=Survivors and Dead Evacuated from Everest Base Camp|author=Photograph Roberto Schmidt, AFP/Getty|publisher=}}</ref> Kedrowski was unhurt by the event and able to help with recovery efforts, as well as collecting data for the USGS about the earthquake.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/climbers-jim-davidson-jon-kedrowski-describe-surviving-everest-avalanche/|title=Climbers recount surviving deadly Everest avalanche|date=11 May 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
==Published works== *"Mapping a Section of the Continental Divide Trail (CDT) in Colorado’s Southern San Juan Wilderness". (2009). ''International Journal of Wilderness'' 15(3): (17-22).<ref>http://ijw.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/04/Dec09-IJW-vol-15-no-3small2.pdf</ref> *"Determining Relative Annual Climbing Frequency of Colorado’s 14,000-foot Peaks". (2009) ''Mountain Research and Development'', 29(1): (82-92).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kedrowski|first1=Jon J.|title=Determining the Relative Annual Mountain Climbing Frequency on Colorado's 14,000-foot Peaks|journal=Mountain Research and Development|volume=29|issue=1|pages=82–92|doi=10.1659/mrd.1053|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/pdf/10.1659/mrd.1053}}</ref> *"Dirty Snow: Documenting the 2009 dust storm events in Colorado’s San Juan and Elk Mountains with repeat photography and historical snowpack data." (2011). ''NWA Online Electronic Journal of Operational Meteorology''. Nov 2010 EJ7. (1-39) https://web.archive.org/web/20160304114234/http://www.nwas.org/ej/pdf/2010-EJ7.pdf *''Sleeping on the Summits: Colorado Fourteener High Bivys'' by Jon Kedrowski and Chris Tomer (2012) <ref>http://www.bigearthpublishing.com/westcliffe-publishers/sleeping-on-the-summits/{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *''Skiing and Sleeping on the Summits: Cascade Volcanoes of the Pacific Northwest Skiing 20 Peaks in 30 Days'' by Jon Kedrowski (2016) <ref>http://www.mountaineersbooks.org/Skiing-and-Sleeping-on-the-Summits-Cascade-Volcanoes-of-the-Pacific-Northwest-P1675.aspx</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.jonkedrowski.com Kedrowski's personal webpage]
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kedrowski, Jon}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American mountain climbers]] [[Category:American geographers]]

{{primary sources|year=December 2009|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox company | name = Jordan Media City
المدينــة الإعلاميـة الأردنيــة | logo = | type = Private | foundation = {{start date and age|2001}} | location = [[Amman]], [[Jordan]] | key_people = Radhi Al Khass
(Executive Director) | industry = [[Mass media|Media]] | homepage = [http://www.jordanmediacity.com JMC website] }} '''Jordan Media City''' is a media city based in [[Jordan]]. ==History and profile== Jordan Media City was established in 2001.{{cite web|title=Middle East Media on the Move|url=http://www.atkearney.com.tr/documents/10192/4095877b-119c-492b-a236-219098f229df|publisher=AT kearney|accessdate=2 October 2014}} It is a private company founded as a result of an agreement between the government of the [[Hashemite kingdom]] of Jordan and Dallah Production Company. It was set up with a capital of ten million [[Jordanian dinar|JD]]s (15 million US Dollars).[http://www.jordanmediacity.com/about_us.shtm JMC - About JMC] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104115158/http://www.jordanmediacity.com/about_us.shtm |date=2010-01-04 }} It now transmits over 247 channels and retransmitts 57 radio broadcasts. Most channels are not Jordanian based, and the government still possess restrictions on Jordanian based channels which makes it hard to open new Jordanian TV channels.[http://www.jordanmediacity.com/en/4/Transmission][http://www.arabadvisors.com/files/reports/TOC-%20Media/ArabAdvisors-MediaTrends-DMC%20Tenants-0804-TOC.pdf Media Trends.] Arab Advisors. Jordan Media City is centrally located next to [[Jordan Radio and Television]] Station. It is a short distance from [[Queen Alia International Airport]], and just a few minutes away from Jordan's main highway which connects the country's northern borders with its only port in [[Aqaba]] in the south. == List of companies == The list below is incomplete. * [[Arab Radio and Television Network|ART]] (headquarters) * [[eqra']] (headquarters) * [[Ro'ya TV]] (headquarters) == See also == *[[Dubai Media City]] *[[IMPZ]] *[[Twofour54]] *[[Creative City]] *[[Ras Al Khaimah Media Free Zone and Film City]] *[[Egyptian Media Production City]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.jordanmediacity.com/ Jordan Media City (official website)] {{Coord|31|54|22|N|35|55|53|E|display=title}} {{media cities in the Arab World}} [[Category:Special economic zones]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Amman|Media City]] [[Category:Jordanian culture|Media City]] [[Category:Economy of Jordan|Media City]] [[Category:Geography of Jordan|Media City]] [[Category:2001 establishments in Jordan]] [[Category:Media in Amman]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Coord|35|36|N|74|39|E|display=title}} {{Infobox road |country = PAK |type = N |route = 35 |alternate_name = Karakoram Highway
{{Nastaliq|'''شاہراہ قراقرم'''}} |ahn = {{AHN-AH|4}} [[Asian Highway]] [[AH4|4]] |length_km= 1300 |length_notes = Pakistan: {{convert|887|km|mi|0|abbr=on}}
China: {{convert|413|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} |direction_a = North |terminus_a = {{Flagicon|PRC}} [[Kashgar]], Xinjiang, China
[[File:Kokudou 314(China).svg|30px]] [[China National Highway 314]] (Khunjerab Pass–Kashgar–[[Ürümqi]])
{{Flagicon|PRC}}{{Flagicon|PAK}} [[Khunjerab Pass]] |cities = [[Haripur, Pakistan|Haripur]], [[Abbottabad]], [[Mansehra]], [[Battagram]], [[Besham]], [[Pattan, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|Pattan]], [[Dasu]], [[Chilas]], [[Gilgit]], [[Aliabad (Hunza)|Aliabad]], [[Gulmit]], [[Sust]], [[Tashkurgan Town|Tashkurgan]], [[Upal]], [[Kashgar]] |direction_b = South |terminus_b = {{Flagicon|PAK}} [[Hasan Abdal]], Punjab, Pakistan |formed = 1966 |history = Completed in 1979, open to the public since 1986 |junction = [[File:Pakistan N-35.svg|30px|35]] N-35
[[File:Pakistan N-15.svg|30px|N-15|link=N15 National Highway]] [[N-15 National Highway|N-15]] |maint = [[National Highway Authority (Pakistan)]] and Transport Department of [[Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region]] (China) }} {{Chinese |s = 喀喇昆仑公路 |p = Kèlǎkūnlún Gōnglù |lang2 = ur |lang2_content = شاہراہ قراقرم
śāharāha qarāqaram }} The '''Karakoram Highway''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|شاہراہ قراقرم}}}}, also known as '''N-35''' or '''National Highway 35''' ({{lang-ur|{{nastaliq|قومی شاہراہ 35}}}}), or the '''China-Pakistan Friendship Highway''') is a 1300 km [[National Highways of Pakistan|national highway]] which extends from [[Hasan Abdal]] in the [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]] province of [[Pakistan]] to the [[Khunjerab Pass]] in [[Gilgit-Baltistan]], where it crosses into [[China]] and becomes '''[[China National Highway 314]]'''. The highway connects the Pakistani provinces of Punjab, [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] and Gilgit-Baltistan with China's [[Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region]]. The highway is a popular [[tourist attraction]], and is one of the highest paved roads in the world, passing through the [[Karakoram]] mountain range, at {{Coord|36|51|00|N|75|25|40|E|}} at maximum elevation of {{convert|4714|m|ft}} near [[Khunjerab pass]].[http://www.concordiaexpeditions.com/pakistan-jeep_trip.htm Karakoram Hindu Kush] [http://www.lonelyplanet.com/shop_pickandmix/previews/karakoram%20highway-preview.pdf Lonely Planet Karakoram] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011125340/http://www.lonelyplanet.com/shop_pickandmix/previews/karakoram%20highway-preview.pdf |date=11 October 2012 }}It can be argued that the [[Chile Route 27]] is international since it connects to Argentina, and it is {{convert|4810|m|ft}} Due to its high elevation and the difficult conditions in which it was constructed, it is often referred to as the [[Eighth Wonder of the World]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.inautonews.com/list-of-world-record-highways |title=World record highways – Karakoram |access-date=2 October 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111223514/http://www.inautonews.com/list-of-world-record-highways |archive-date=11 November 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite book |title=Roads and Rivals: The Political Uses of Access in the Borderlands of Asia|date=June 1989|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-0801422201|page=191|author=Mahnaz Z. Ispahani|edition=First}}{{Cite report |author=Tanveer Naim|year=2010|title=UNESCO Science Report|chapter=South Asia |url = https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=2ZTLCOe_fqwC&pg=PA342 |publisher=[[UNESCO]]|page=342|isbn=978-9231041327|accessdate=18 July 2013}} The highway is also a part of the [[Asian Highway Network|Asian Highway]] [[AH4]]. == History == [[File:Summits of KKH.jpg|thumb|[[Rakaposhi]] Peak as seen from the Karakoram Highway near Nagar, Gilgit.]] The Karakoram Highway, also known as the Friendship Highway in China, was built by the governments of Pakistan and China. It was started in 1959 and was completed and opened to the public in 1979. Pakistan initially favored routing through [[Mintaka Pass]]. In 1966, China citing the fact that Mintaka would be more susceptible to air strikes recommended the steeper Khunjerab Pass instead.{{Cite web | title = 重寻玄奘之路 | trans-title = Rediscover the path taken by Xuanzang | author = 刘欣 | website = | date = 2013-05-03 | publisher = 东方早报 | accessdate = 2017-02-02 | url = https://site.douban.com/121981/widget/notes/4169991/note/274606907/ | language = zh | quote = 1966年，时任新疆军区副司令员的张希钦在主持修筑中巴公路时，为避敌国空袭，放弃了巴方主张的走宽阔的明铁盖达坂的方案，而取道地势高峻的红其拉甫山口。 }} About 810 Pakistanis and about 200 Chinese workers lost their lives,[http://www.pakpost.gov.pk/philately/stamps2003/karakoram_highway.html 25th Anniversary of the Karakoram Highway (1978–2003)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528060319/http://www.pakpost.gov.pk/philately/stamps2003/karakoram_highway.html |date=28 May 2013 }}". ''Pakistan Post Office,'' 16 May 2006. Retrieved on 10 July 2006. mostly in [[landslides]] and falls, while building the highway. Over 140 Chinese workers who died during the construction are buried in the [[Chinese cemetery, Gilgit|Chinese cemetery]] in Gilgit.{{Cite speech | title = Making New Progress in Growing China-Pakistan All-Weather Friendship | last = Li | first = Keqiang | author-link = Li Keqiang | website = [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China|fmprc.gov.cn]] | date = 2013-05-23 | accessdate = 2017-02-02 | url = http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/topics_665678/lkqipsg_665690/t1043526.shtml | language = en | quote = Near the city of Gilgit, there is a Chinese cemetery where over 140 Chinese workers who lost their lives in the construction of the Pakistani section of the Karakorum Highway (KKH) are buried. }} The route of the KKH traces one of the many paths of the ancient [[Silk Road]]. On the Pakistani side, the road was constructed by [[Frontier Works Organisation|FWO]] (Frontier Works Organisation), employing the [[Pakistan Army Corps of Engineers]]. The Engineer-in-Chief's Branch of the Pakistani Army completed a project documenting the history of the highway. The book ''History of Karakoram Highway'' was written by Brigadier (Retired) Muhammad Mumtaz Khalid in two volumes. In the first volume the author discusses the land and the people, the pre-historic communication system in the Northern Areas, the need for an all-weather road link with [[Gilgit]], and the construction of Indus Valley Road. The second volume records events leading to the conversion of the Indus Valley Road to the Karakoram Highway, the difficulties in its construction, and the role of Pakistan Army Corps of Engineers and their Chinese counterparts in its construction.[https://web.archive.org/web/20130613165212/http://www.historyofkkh.info/ History of KKH by Brigadier (Retired) Muhammad Mumtaz Khalid] == The Highway == [[File:Pakistani truck in Karakoram Highway, Passu, Northern Areas, Pakistan.jpg|thumb|right|[[Jingle truck]]s on Karakoram Highway.]] [[File:Gojal Where Pakistan Begins.jpg|thumb|The highway in [[Gojal]], Upper [[Hunza Valley|Hunza]].]] The highway, connecting the [[Gilgit–Baltistan]] region to the ancient [[Silk Road]], runs approximately {{convert|1300|km|mi|abbr=on}} from [[Kashgar]], a city in the [[Xinjiang]] region of China, to [[Abbottabad]], of Pakistan. An extension of the highway southwest from [[Abbottabad]], in the form of the [[N-35 highway (Pakistan)|N-35 highway]], meets the Grand Trunk Road, [[N5 highway (Pakistan)|N-5]], at [[Hasan Abdal]], Pakistan. The highway cuts through the [[Continental collision#Subduction zone: the collision site|collision zone]] between the [[Eurasian Plate|Eurasian]] and [[Indian plate]]s, where China, [[Tajikistan]], [[Afghanistan]], and [[Pakistan]] come within {{convert|250|km|mi}} of each other. Owing largely to the extremely sensitive state of the [[Kashmir]] conflict between India and Pakistan, the Karakoram Highway has strategic and military importance to these nations, but particularly Pakistan and China. On 30 June 2006, a [[memorandum of understanding]] was signed between the Pakistani [[National Highway Authority]] (NHA) and China's [[State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission]] (SASAC) to rebuild and upgrade the Karakoram Highway. According to SASAC, the width will be expanded from {{convert|10|to|30|m}}, and its transport capacity will be increased three times its current capacity. In addition, the upgraded road will be designed to particularly accommodate heavy-laden vehicles and extreme weather conditions. China and Pakistan are planning to link the Karakoram Highway to the southern port of [[Gwadar port|Gwadar]] in [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] through the Chinese-aided [[Gwadar]]-[[Dalbandin]] railway, which extends to [[Rawalpindi]]. On 4 January 2010, the KKH was closed in the [[Hunza Valley]], eliminating through traffic to China except by small boats. A massive [[landslide]] {{convert|15|km|mi}} upstream from Hunza's capital of [[Karimabad (Hunza)|Karimabad]] created the potentially unstable [[Attabad Lake]], which reached {{convert|22|km|mi}} in length and over {{convert|100|m|ft}} in depth by the first week of June 2010 when it finally began flowing over the landslide dam. The landslide destroyed parts of villages while killing many inhabitants. The subsequent lake displaced thousands and inundated over {{convert|20|km|mi}} of the KKH including the {{convert|310|m|ft}} long KKH bridge {{convert|4|km|mi}} south of [[Gulmit]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/Lahore/10-Mar-2010/Thousands-at-risk-due-to-Hunza-river-blockade |title=Thousands at risk due to Hunza river blockade |access-date=7 May 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100617040400/http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/Lahore/10-Mar-2010/Thousands-at-risk-due-to-Hunza-river-blockade |archive-date=17 June 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}[http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/sci-tech/03-rising-water-threatens-villages-in-hunza-ss-03 Search Results rising water threatens villages in hunza ss | Latest news, Breaking news, Pakistan News, World news, business, sport and multimedia | DAWN.COM][http://gilgity.blogspot.com Blockage of Hunza river, Landslide blog written by Shakeelgilgity, Gilgit-Baltistan] It is highly questionable whether the lake, which reached {{convert|27|km|mi}} in length in 2011, will drain. Goods from and to further north are transported over the lake by small vessels, to be reloaded onto trucks at the other end.[http://www.indianexpress.com/news/landslide-cuts-crucial-chinapak-road-link-hits-military-supplies/627104/0 Landslide cuts crucial China-Pak road link, hits military supplies – Indian Express] In July 2012 Pakistan began constructing a revised route around the lake at a higher elevation with five new tunnels, with total length of 7.12 km, and two new bridges. The work was contracted out to the China Road & Bridge Corporation (CRBC) and was completed in September 2015—see [[Karakorum Highway|Karakorum Highway Realignment (China-Pakistan Friendship Tunnels)]] below.{{Cite news|author1=Khan, Asghar |author2=Khan, Zulfiqar Ali |title=KKH Re-Alignment: 94% work on the project completed so far, remaining to be completed by Sep. 25 this year |date=27 June 2015 |newspaper=Pamir Times |url=http://pamirtimes.net/2015/06/27/kkh-re-alignment-94-work-on-the-project-completed-so-far-remaining-to-be-completed-by-sep-25-this-year/ |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150627164303/http://pamirtimes.net/2015/06/27/kkh-re-alignment-94-work-on-the-project-completed-so-far-remaining-to-be-completed-by-sep-25-this-year/ |archivedate=27 June 2015 |deadurl = no }} === Pakistani section === [[File:Start Karkoram Highway.jpg|right|thumb|220px|Milestone near Besham in [[Pakistan]].]] At {{convert|806|km|mi}} in lengthhttp://downloads.nha.gov.pk/images/stories/services/routedistance/rd4.jpg, the Pakistani section of the highway starts at [[Abbottabad]], although the [[N-35 highway (Pakistan)|N-35]] of which KKH is now part, officially starts from Hasan Abdal. The highway meets the [[Indus River]] at [[Thakot]] and continues along the river until [[Jaglot]], where the [[Gilgit River]] joins the [[Indus River]]. This is where three great mountain ranges meet: the [[Hindukush]], the [[Himalaya]], and the [[Karakoram]]. The western end of the Himalayas, marked by the ninth highest peak in the world, [[Nanga Parbat]], can be seen from the highway. The highway passes through the capital of [[Gilgit–Baltistan]], [[Gilgit]], and continues through the valleys of [[Nagar Valley|Nagar]] and [[Hunza Valley|Hunza]], along the [[Hunza River]]. Some of the highest mountains and famous [[glaciers]] in the [[Karakoram]] can be seen in this section. The highway meets the Pakistani-Chinese border at [[Khunjerab Pass]]. == Karakoram Highway reconstruction == {{Main article|Reconstruction of the Karakoram Highway}} [[File:KKHReconstructions.png|260px|thumb|Highlighted in red is the route of National Highway 35, which is to be completely rebuilt and upgraded under the CPEC agreement. Highlighted in blue is the 175-kilometre road between [[Gilgit]] and [[Skardu]] which is to be upgraded to a 4-lane highway.]] As part of the $46 billion '''[[China Pakistan Economic Corridor]]''', reconstruction and upgrade works on the Pakistani portion of the Karakoram Highway (KKH) are underway. The KKH spans the 806-kilometre-long distance between the China-Pakistan border and the town of [[Hasan Abdal]]. At [[Burhan Interchange]] near Hasan Abdal, the existing [[M1 motorway (Pakistan)|M1 motorway]] will intersect the Karakoram Highway. From there, access onwards to Islamabad and Lahore continues as part of the existing M1 and M2 motorways, while Hasan Abdal will also be at intersection of the [[China–Pakistan Economic Corridor#Eastern Alignment|Eastern Alignment]], and the [[Western Alignment]] which will lead towards the port city of [[Gwadar]]. === Karakoram Highway Realignment (China-Pakistan Friendship Tunnels) === A large section of the highway was damaged by a landslide in 2010 that created [[Attabad Lake]]. The resulting landslides cut off both the Hunza River and Karakoram Highway resulting in the formation of the reservoir. Prior to completion of the bypass, all vehicular traffic had to be loaded onto boats to traverse the new reservoir. Construction of the tunnels began in 2012 and required 36 months for completion. The 24 km-long series of bridges and tunnels was inaugurated on 15 September 2015 at a cost of $275 million and was hailed as a major accomplishment.http://www.dawn.com/news/1206911http://tribune.com.pk/story/956452/pm-inaugurates-tunnel-over-attabad-lake-in-g-b/ The route comprises 5 tunnels and several bridges. The longest tunnel is 3360 m, followed by 2736 m, 435 m, 410 m and 195 m, while the Shishkat Great Bridge on [[Hunza River]] is 480 m long. The realignment restored the road link between Pakistan and China. === Chinese section === [[File:Karakorum-carretera-d08.jpg|right|thumb|220px|The Karakoram Highway in the [[Xinjiang]] region of [[People's Republic of China|China]].]] The Chinese section of the Karakoram Highway follows the north-south Sarykol ("Yellow Lake") valley just west of the [[Tarim Basin]]. The road from Kashgar goes southwest about {{convert|80|km|mi}} and then turns west to enter the Gez (Ghez) River canyon between [[Chakragil]] mountain on the north and [[Kongur]] mountain on the south. From the Gez canyon the population becomes Kirgiz. Having climbed up to the valley, the road turns south past Kongur, [[Karakul (China)|Karakul Lake]], and [[Muztagh Ata]] on the east. Below Muztagh Ata, a new road goes west over the [[Kulma Pass]] to join the [[Pamir Highway]] in [[Gorno-Badakhshan]], Tajikistan. The main road continues over a low pass (where the population becomes Tajik) and descends to [[Tashkurgan Town|Tashkurgan]]. Further south, a valley and jeep track leads west toward the [[Wakhjir Pass]] to the [[Wakhan Corridor]]. Next the road turns west to a checkpost and small settlement at Pirali, and then the [[Khunjerab Pass]], beyond which is Pakistan, the Khunjerab River and [[Hunza Valley|Hunza]]. === Major towns === [[File:Cathedral Ridge Passu NEFrontier Pakistan.jpg|right|thumb|220px|KKH passing through [[Passu]] in [[Pakistan]].]] * [[Islamabad-Rawalpindi metropolitan area|Rawalpindi Islamabad]] * [[Hassan Abdal]] * [[Haripur, Pakistan|Haripur]] * [[Abbottabad]] * [[Mansehra]] * [[Battagram]] * [[Besham]] * [[Pattan, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|Pattan]] * [[Kohistan District, Pakistan|Kohistan]] * [[Dasu]] * [[Chilas]] * [[Juglot]] * [[Gilgit]] * [[Nagar, Pakistan|Nagar]] * [[Aliabad (Hunza)|Aliabad]] * [[Gulmit]] * [[Sust]] * [[Tashkurgan Town|Tashkurgan]] (China) * [[Upal]] (China) * [[Kashgar]], Chinese [[railhead]], {{RailGauge|1435mm}} [[Rail gauge|gauge]] == Tourism == In recent years the highway has sought to become a 'niche' [[Adventure travel|adventure tourism]] destination although Pakistan attracts few international tourists compared to domestic ones. But in recent years, owing to the improved security situation in the country, the number of foreign tourists coming to Pakistan has more than tripled since 2013, standing at 1.75 million in 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1360604|title=Foreign tourists to Pakistan more than triple since 2013|last=|first=|date=30 September 2017|website=Dawn|access-date=}} Among the tourist destinations in the country, KKH is deemed as the "third best" by ''[[The Guardian]]''.{{cite news |url = https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2006/oct/17/pakistan?page=all |work = The Guardian |location = London |title = Out of the rubble |first = Antonia |last = Windsor |date = 17 October 2006 |accessdate = 7 May 2010 }} The road has given [[mountaineers]] and cyclists easier access to the many high mountains, glaciers, and lakes in the area. The highway provides access to [[Gilgit]] and [[Skardu]] from [[Islamabad]] by road. These are the two major hubs for mountaineering expeditions in the [[Gilgit–Baltistan]] region of Pakistan-administered Kashmir.''Pakistan and the Karakoram Highway'', Owen Bennett-Jones, Lindsay Brown, and John Mock, Lonely Planet Publications; 6 Rev Ed edition (30 Sep 2004), {{ISBN|0-86442-709-3}} The Gilgit–Baltistan Administration of Pakistan-administered Kashmir and the Xinjiang Administration of China have signed an agreement to issue border passes to their permanent residents. This pass is valid for a calendar year and is used to travel through Khunjerab Pass only. Karakoram Highway has been described as one of the most beautiful destinations in the world. KKH provides a cross country road trip from Hasan Abdal, Pakistan to Kashghar. {{cite web |last1 = Karakoram Highway |first1 = Road Trip |title = Karakoram Highway Cross Country Road Trip |url = http://www.skardu.pk/karakoram-highway-road-trip-cross-country-adventure-in-gilgit-baltistan/ |website = www.skardu.pk |publisher = Skardu.pk |accessdate = 23 November 2016 }} === Mountains and glaciers === [[File:Baltistan.jpg|right|thumb|220px|KKH along the [[Indus River]], 2001.]] Karakoram Highway provides the pathway to expeditions for almost all peaks in [[Gilgit–Baltistan]], Kashmir and several peaks in [[Xinjiang]] China. The region includes some of the world's largest glaciers like the [[Baltoro Glacier|Baltoro and Siachen Glaciers]]. Five of the [[Eight-thousander]]s (mountains taller than {{convert|8000|m|ft}}) of the world that are in [[Pakistan]] are accessible by the highway. The notable mountains that can be directly seen while travelling on the highway are: * [[Nanga Parbat]], [[Gilgit–Baltistan]], 9th highest of the world at {{convert|8126|m|ft}} * [[Rakaposhi]], [[Gilgit–Baltistan]], 27th highest of the world at {{convert|7788|m|ft}} * [[Diran]], [[Gilgit–Baltistan]], most dangerous mountain in [[Pakistan]] * Shishpar, [[Gilgit–Baltistan]], * [[Ultar Peak]], [[Gilgit–Baltistan]], * Tupopdan, [[Gilgit–Baltistan]], also known as Cathedral Peaks near [[Passu]] Many glaciers can be seen while travelling on the highway: * Minapin Glacier * Passu Glacier * Ghulkin Glacier * Khunjerab Glacier === Rivers and lakes === [[File:Karakoram Highway .jpg|thumb|230px|Karakoram Highway near [[Juglot|Juglo]]t, where three mightiest mountain ranges meet]] Several rivers and lakes are made accessible by the highway. These include: * [[Indus River]] * [[Hunza River]] * [[Attabad Lake]] * [[Gilgit River]] * [[Khunjerab River]] * [[Karakul (China)|Karakul Lake]] in Xinjiang (China) === Rock art and petroglyphs === {{Main article|Northern Areas, Pakistan#Rock art and petroglyphs}} [[File:Shattial Carvings.JPG|thumb|On the Karokoram Highway near Chilas.]] There are more than 50,000 pieces of rock art and [[petroglyph]]s all along the highway that are concentrated at ten major sites between [[Hunza Valley|Hunza]] and [[Shatial]]. The carvings were left by invaders, traders, and [[pilgrims]] who passed along the trade route, as well as by locals. The earliest date back to between 5000 and 1000 BC, showing single animals, triangular men, and hunting scenes in which the animals are larger than the hunters. These [[Stone carving|carvings]] were pecked into the rock with stone tools and are covered with a thick [[patina]] that yields their age. === Travel === There are several transport companies in Pakistan that offer bus service between major towns of the highway and from [[Rawalpindi]] and [[Lahore]]. The largest company is [[Northern Areas Transport Corporation]] (NATCO). Other companies are Masherbrum Travel, Silk Route Travel, K-2 movers, Anchan Travel, and Saeed Travel. === Bus service between Gilgit and Kashghar === On 1 June 2006, a daily bus service began between [[Gilgit]], [[Gilgit–Baltistan]], and [[Kashghar]], Xinjiang, through the [[Sust]] and [[Tashkurgan Tajik Autonomous County|Tashkorgan]] border area.{{cite news |url = http://www.dawn.com/2006/03/23/nat2.htm |title=Kashghar-Gilgit bus service planned |newspaper=[[DAWN (newspaper)|DAWN Newspaper]] |date = 23 March 2006 |dead-url = yes |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090215045454/http://www.dawn.com/2006/03/23/nat2.htm |archive-date = 15 February 2009 }} == Weather == The KKH is best travelled in the spring or early autumn. Heavy snow during harsh winters can shut the highway down for extended periods. Heavy [[monsoon]] rains around July and August cause occasional [[landslides]] that can block the road for hours or more. The border crossing between China and [[Pakistan]] at [[Khunjerab Pass]] is open only between 1 May and 31 December. == See also == {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} * [[Attabad Lake]] * [[Edicts of [[File:Surface with path of greatest slope.png|thumb|431px|A surface showing one example (approximate) of a path of greatest slope (red path).]] In [[topography]], the '''line of greatest slope''' is a curve following the steepest [[slope]]. In [[Downhill mountain biking|mountain biking]] and [[alpine skiing|skiing]], the line of greatest slope is sometimes called the [[Fall line (topography)|fall line]].<ref name="rr">[https://rootsrated.com/brevard-nc/mountain-biking/farlow-gap https://rootsrated.com] Farlow Gap – Mountain Biking: fall line (2nd paragraph) — "The trail becomes loose and rocky, and becomes fall line into a wide open rock garden..."</ref>
==Definition== Mathematically, the line (or path) of greatest slope from a point is determined by the [[gradient]] of height, taken as a [[potential|potential field]] with respect to an acceleration from the force of gravity. Lines of greatest slope are analogous to [[line of force|lines of force]] acting to accelerate an object downward at that point.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} These lines are [[orthogonal]] to [[contour line]]s. Discounting [[inertial force]]s and terrain roughness, a ball rolling down a slope, or water flowing down, will accelerate in the direction of greatest slope.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
==Applications== ===Mountain biking=== [[File:Emmeline-Ragot.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|A [[Mountain biking|mountain biker]] riding a trail which follows the line of greatest slope, or [[Fall line (topography)|fall line]].]] In [[mountain biking]] the line of greatest slope defines the [[Fall line (topography)|fall line]], which is the path a trail will follow to descend a hill or mountain with the shortest path,<ref name="rr"/> and will also cause the rider to gain the most velocity (assuming brakes are not used, and other factors such as rolling resistance are equal).
===Mountain climbing=== [[File:Contour map with an example fall line.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|The line of greatest slope defines the path (red) a climber will take to gain the most elevation with the shortest possible path.]] In [[Mountaineering|mountain climbing]], the line of greatest slope defines the fall line, which is the path a climber will take to gain the most elevation with the shortest possible path.
===Map reading=== The line of greatest slope has practical significance in map reading. On the terrain it is often far more discernible, even intuitively obvious, rather than accurately picking out the consistent height level on what is likely the undulating uneven ground along the ground represented on the contour line. But knowing that a greatest slope vector is orthogonal to the contour line, one can readily deduce the direction of the contour lines from the line of greatest slope. The extent and overall direction of the contour line to a map scale can only be found on the topographic map.
By noting the corresponding compass vector, walking along the contour one can line up a hand held compass aligning the expected direction, and eye-balling the line of contour's estimated level, move up or down along the bearing faster— to closely locate a desired point (planned point) along the hillside.{{Clarify|date=June 2017}} Pragmatically, this can be 'good enough' for rough project landscaping, such as timber clear cutting the work site of a structure like a [[bridge]] [[abutment]] or connecting ramps. The approximation can then be refined by transit and other surveyor tools to construct on target.
==See also== * [[Slope]] * [[Fall line (topography)]] * [[Surface (topology)]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Use British English|date=June 2012}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''My Hero'' episodes}} The following is a list of episodes of the [[BBC]] comedy series '''''[[My Hero (UK TV series)|My Hero]]''''', starring [[Ardal O'Hanlon]] as Ultronian superhero George Sunday and [[Emily Joyce]] as his human wife, Janet. Six series were broadcast between 2000 and 2006.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/guide/articles/m/myhero_66602550.shtml ''My Hero''] at the BBC Comedy Guide. Each series featured a varying number of episodes, with the first and second series containing six episodes, series three through five containing ten episodes each and series six containing eight episodes.[https://web.archive.org/web/20080905080726/http://www.bigbearfilms.co.uk/myhero.htm ''My Hero''] at Big Bear Films home page The first series was the only series to include a Christmas Special.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/my-hero/show/3671/summary.html?tag=login;dropdown|title=My Hero|website=TV.com|accessdate=26 July 2018}} Although the series gathered consistent viewing figures, figures for the sixth series declined heavily following the appointment of [[James Dreyfus]] to replace outgoing lead actor O'Hanlon.{{cite web|url=http://www.phill.co.uk/comedy/hero/index.html|title=My Hero (Summary)|website=Phill.co.uk|accessdate=26 July 2018}} The series was subsequently axed in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.sitcom.co.uk/my_hero/|title=My Hero - BBC1 Sitcom - British Comedy Guide|website=British Comedy Guide|accessdate=26 July 2018}} Three of the six series have been released on DVD; two on [[Region 1 DVD]] and one on Region 2.[https://web.archive.org/web/20080720031824/http://www.bbcamerica.com/genre/comedy_games/my_hero/my_hero.jsp ''My Hero''] at BBC America. Fans have since petitioned the [[BBC]] to release the complete series on DVD.[https://web.archive.org/web/20080608151858/http://www.downthetubes.net/tv/my_hero/ ''My Hero''] News, episode guide and interviews at downthetubes.net ==Overview== {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2"|Series !!
